text: When Moses went into the tent of meeting to speak with the Lord, he would hear the voice speaking to him from above the cover that was on the ark of the covenant from between the two cherubim; thus it spoke to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to Aaron and say to him: When you set up the lamps, the seven lamps shall give light in front of the lampstand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron did so; he set up its lamps in front of the lampstand, as the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now this was how the lampstand was made, out of hammered work of gold. From its base to its flowers, it was hammered work; according to the pattern that the Lord had shown Moses, so he made the lampstand.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the Levites from among the Israelites and cleanse them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus you shall do to them, to cleanse them: sprinkle the water of purification on them; have them shave their whole body with a razor and wash their clothes and so cleanse themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then let them take a young bull and its grain offering of choice flour mixed with oil, and you shall take another young bull for a purification offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall bring the Levites before the tent of meeting and assemble the whole congregation of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you bring the Levites before the Lord, the Israelites shall lay their hands on the Levites,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Aaron shall present the Levites before the Lord as an elevation offering from the Israelites, that they may do the service of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites shall lay their hands on the heads of the bulls, and he shall offer the one for a purification offering and the other for a burnt offering to the Lord, to make atonement for the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you shall have the Levites stand before Aaron and his sons, and you shall present them as an elevation offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Thus you shall separate the Levites from among the other Israelites, and the Levites shall be mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thereafter the Levites may go in to do service at the tent of meeting, once you have cleansed them and presented them as an elevation offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they are unreservedly given to me from among the Israelites; I have taken them for myself, in place of all that open the womb, the firstborn of all the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all the firstborn among the Israelites are mine, both human and animal. On the day that I struck down all the firstborn in the land of Egypt I consecrated them for myself,
speaker: Narrator

text: but I have taken the Levites in place of all the firstborn among the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, I have given the Levites as a gift to Aaron and his sons from among the Israelites, to do the service for the Israelites at the tent of meeting and to make atonement for the Israelites, in order that there may be no plague among the Israelites for coming too close to the sanctuary.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron and the whole congregation of the Israelites did with the Levites accordingly; the Israelites did with the Levites just as the Lord had commanded Moses concerning them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites purified themselves from sin and washed their clothes; then Aaron presented them as an elevation offering before the Lord, and Aaron made atonement for them to cleanse them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thereafter the Levites went in to do their service in the tent of meeting in attendance on Aaron and his sons. As the Lord had commanded Moses concerning the Levites, so they did with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This applies to the Levites: from twenty-five years old and up they shall begin to do duty in the service of the tent of meeting;
speaker: Narrator

text: and from the age of fifty years they shall retire from the duty of the service and serve no more.
speaker: Narrator

text: They may assist their brothers in the tent of meeting in carrying out their duties, but they shall perform no service. Thus you shall do with the Levites in assigning their duties.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses in the wilderness of Sinai, in the first month of the second year after they had come out of the land of Egypt, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let the Israelites keep the Passover at its appointed time.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fourteenth day of this month, at twilight, you shall keep it at its appointed time; according to all its statutes and all its regulations you shall keep it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses told the Israelites that they should keep the Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: They kept the Passover in the first month, on the fourteenth day of the month, at twilight, in the wilderness of Sinai. Just as the Lord had commanded Moses, so the Israelites did.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there were certain people who were unclean through touching a corpse, so that they could not keep the Passover on that day. They came before Moses and Aaron on that day
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to him, “Although we are unclean through touching a corpse, why must we be kept from presenting the Lord’s offering at its appointed time among the Israelites?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to them, “Wait, so that I may hear what the Lord will command concerning you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites, saying: Anyone of you or your descendants who is unclean through touching a corpse or is away on a journey shall still keep the Passover to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the second month on the fourteenth day, at twilight, they shall keep it; they shall eat it with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall leave none of it until morning nor break a bone of it; according to all the statute for the Passover they shall keep it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But anyone who is clean and is not on a journey and yet refrains from keeping the Passover shall be cut off from the people for not presenting the Lord’s offering at its appointed time; such a one shall bear the consequences for the sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any alien residing among you who wishes to keep the Passover to the Lord shall do so according to the statute of the Passover and according to its regulation; you shall have one statute for both the resident alien and the native of the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day the tabernacle was set up, the cloud covered the tabernacle, the tent of the covenant, and from evening until morning it was over the tabernacle, having the appearance of fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was always so: the cloud covered it by day and the appearance of fire by night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the cloud lifted from over the tent, then the Israelites would set out, and in the place where the cloud settled down, there the Israelites would camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the command of the Lord the Israelites would set out, and at the command of the Lord they would camp. As long as the cloud rested over the tabernacle, they would remain in camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even when the cloud continued over the tabernacle many days, the Israelites would keep the charge of the Lord and would not set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sometimes the cloud would remain a few days over the tabernacle, and according to the command of the Lord they would remain in camp; then according to the command of the Lord they would set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sometimes the cloud would remain from evening until morning, and when the cloud lifted in the morning, they would set out, or if it continued for a day and a night, when the cloud lifted they would set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whether it was two days or a month or a longer time that the cloud continued over the tabernacle, resting upon it, the Israelites would remain in camp and would not set out, but when it lifted they would set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the command of the Lord they would camp, and at the command of the Lord they would set out. They kept the charge of the Lord, at the command of the Lord by Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make two silver trumpets; you shall make them of hammered work, and you shall use them for summoning the congregation and for breaking camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: When both are blown, the whole congregation shall assemble before you at the entrance of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if only one is blown, then the leaders, the heads of the tribes of Israel, shall assemble before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you blow an alarm, the camps on the east side shall set out;
speaker: Narrator

text: when you blow a second alarm, the camps on the south side shall set out. An alarm is to be blown whenever they are to set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the assembly is to be gathered, you shall blow, but you shall not sound an alarm.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Aaron, the priests, shall blow the trumpets; this shall be a perpetual institution for you throughout your generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you go to war in your land against the adversary who oppresses you, you shall sound an alarm with the trumpets, so that you may be remembered before the Lord your God and be saved from your enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also on your days of rejoicing, at your appointed festivals, and at the beginnings of your months, you shall blow the trumpets over your burnt offerings and over your sacrifices of well-being; they shall serve as a reminder on your behalf before the Lord your God: I am the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the second year, in the second month, on the twentieth day of the month, the cloud lifted from over the tabernacle of the covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Israelites set out by stages from the wilderness of Sinai, and the cloud settled down in the wilderness of Paran.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set out for the first time at the command of the Lord by Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The standard of the camp of Judah set out first, company by company, and over the whole company was Nahshon son of Amminadab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Over the company of the tribe of Issachar was Nethanel son of Zuar,
speaker: Narrator

text: and over the company of the tribe of Zebulun was Eliab son of Helon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the tabernacle was taken down, and the Gershonites and the Merarites, who carried the tabernacle, set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next the standard of the camp of Reuben set out, company by company, and over the whole company was Elizur son of Shedeur.
speaker: Narrator

text: Over the company of the tribe of Simeon was Shelumiel son of Zurishaddai,
speaker: Narrator

text: and over the company of the tribe of Gad was Eliasaph son of Deuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Kohathites, who carried the holy things, set out, and the tabernacle was set up before their arrival.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next the standard of the camp of Ephraim set out, company by company, and over the whole company was Elishama son of Ammihud.
speaker: Narrator

text: Over the company of the tribe of Manasseh was Gamaliel son of Pedahzur,
speaker: Narrator

text: and over the company of the tribe of Benjamin was Abidan son of Gideoni.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the standard of the camp of Dan, acting as the rear guard of all the camps, set out, company by company, and over the whole company was Ahiezer son of Ammishaddai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Over the company of the tribe of Asher was Pagiel son of Ochran,
speaker: Narrator

text: and over the company of the tribe of Naphtali was Ahira son of Enan.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the order of march of the Israelites, company by company, when they set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Hobab son of Reuel the Midianite, Moses’s father-in-law, “We are setting out for the place of which the Lord said, ‘I will give it to you’; come with us, and we will treat you well, for the Lord has promised good to Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said to him, “I will not go, but I will go back to my own land and to my kindred.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Do not leave us, for you know where we should camp in the wilderness, and you will serve as eyes for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, if you go with us, whatever good the Lord does for us, the same we will do for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they set out from the mount of the Lord three days’ journey with the ark of the covenant of the Lord going before them three days’ journey, to seek out a resting place for them,
speaker: Narrator

text: the cloud of the Lord being over them by day when they set out from the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whenever the ark set out, Moses would say,
“Arise, O Lord, let your enemies be scattered
    and your foes flee before you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And whenever it came to rest, he would say,
“Return, O Lord, to the ten thousand thousands of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when the people complained in the hearing of the Lord about their misfortunes, the Lord heard it, and his anger was kindled. Then the fire of the Lord burned against them and consumed some outlying parts of the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people cried out to Moses, and Moses prayed to the Lord, and the fire abated.
speaker: Narrator

text: So that place was called Taberah, because the fire of the Lord burned against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The camp followers with them had a strong craving, and the Israelites also wept again and said, “If only we had meat to eat!
speaker: Narrator

text: We remember the fish we used to eat in Egypt for nothing, the cucumbers, the melons, the leeks, the onions, and the garlic,
speaker: Narrator

text: but now our strength is dried up, and there is nothing at all but this manna to look at.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the manna was like coriander seed, and its color was like the color of gum resin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people went around and gathered it, ground it in mills or beat it in mortars, then boiled it in pots and made cakes of it, and the taste of it was like the taste of cakes baked with oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the dew fell on the camp in the night, the manna would fall with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses heard the people weeping throughout their families, all at the entrances of their tents. Then the Lord became very angry, and Moses was displeased.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses said to the Lord, “Why have you treated your servant so badly? Why have I not found favor in your sight, that you lay the burden of all this people on me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Did I conceive all this people? Did I give birth to them, that you should say to me, ‘Carry them in your bosom as a wet nurse carries a nursing child, to the land that you promised on oath to their ancestors’?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where am I to get meat to give to all this people? For they come weeping to me, saying, ‘Give us meat to eat!’
speaker: Narrator

text: I am not able to carry all this people alone, for they are too heavy for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If this is the way you are going to treat me, put me to death at once—if I have found favor in your sight—and do not let me see my misery.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said to Moses, “Gather for me seventy of the elders of Israel, whom you know to be the elders of the people and officers over them; bring them to the tent of meeting and have them take their place there with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will come down and speak with you there, and I will take some of the spirit that is on you and put it on them, and they shall bear the burden of the people along with you so that you will not bear it all by yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text: And say to the people, ‘Consecrate yourselves for tomorrow, and you shall eat meat, for you have wailed in the hearing of the Lord, saying, “If only we had meat to eat! Surely it was better for us in Egypt.” Therefore the Lord will give you meat, and you shall eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall eat not only one day, or two days, or five days, or ten days, or twenty days,
speaker: Narrator

text: but for a whole month, until it comes out of your nostrils and becomes loathsome to you—because you have rejected the Lord who is among you and have wailed before him, saying, “Why did we ever leave Egypt?” ’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “The people I am with number six hundred thousand on foot, and you say, ‘I will give them meat, that they may eat for a whole month’!
speaker: Narrator

text: Are there enough flocks and herds to slaughter for them? Are there enough fish in the sea to catch for them?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Is the Lord’s power limited? Now you shall see whether my word will come true for you or not.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went out and told the people the words of the Lord, and he gathered seventy of the elders of the people and placed them all around the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord came down in the cloud and spoke to him and took some of the spirit that was on him and put it on the seventy elders, and when the spirit rested upon them, they prophesied. But they did not do so again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two men remained in the camp, one named Eldad and the other named Medad, and the spirit rested on them; they were among those registered, but they had not gone out to the tent, so they prophesied in the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: And a young man ran and told Moses, “Eldad and Medad are prophesying in the camp.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Joshua son of Nun, the assistant of Moses, one of his chosen men, said, “My lord Moses, stop them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said to him, “Are you jealous for my sake? Would that all the Lord’s people were prophets and that the Lord would put his spirit on them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses and the elders of Israel returned to the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a wind went out from the Lord, and it brought quails from the sea and let them fall beside the camp, about a day’s journey on this side and a day’s journey on the other side, all around the camp, about two cubits deep on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people worked all that day and night and all the next day gathering the quails; the least anyone gathered was ten homers, and they spread them out for themselves all around the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: But while the meat was still between their teeth, before it was consumed, the anger of the Lord was kindled against the people, and the Lord struck the people with a very great plague.
speaker: Narrator

text: So that place was called Kibroth-hattaavah, because there they buried the people who had the craving.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Kibroth-hattaavah the people journeyed to Hazeroth.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were at Hazeroth, Miriam and Aaron spoke against Moses because of the Cushite woman whom he had married (for he had indeed married a Cushite woman),
speaker: Narrator

text: and they said, “Has the Lord spoken only through Moses? Has he not spoken through us also?” And the Lord heard it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the man Moses was very humble, more so than anyone else on the face of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly the Lord said to Moses, Aaron, and Miriam, “Come out, you three, to the tent of meeting.” So the three of them came out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord came down in a pillar of cloud and stood at the entrance of the tent and called Aaron and Miriam, and they both came forward.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And he said, “Hear my words:
When there are prophets among you,
    I the Lord make myself known to them in visions;
    I speak to them in dreams.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Not so with my servant Moses;
    he is faithful in all my house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With him I speak face to face—clearly, not in riddles,
    and he beholds the form of the Lord.
“Why then were you not afraid to speak against my servant Moses?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the anger of the Lord was kindled against them, and he departed.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the cloud went away from over the tent, Miriam’s skin had become diseased, as white as snow. And Aaron turned toward Miriam and saw that she was diseased.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron said to Moses, “Oh, my lord, do not punish us for a sin that we have so foolishly committed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not let her be like one stillborn, whose flesh is half consumed when it comes out of its mother’s womb.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses cried to the Lord, saying, “O God, please heal her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Moses, “If her father had but spit in her face, would she not bear her shame for seven days? Let her be shut out of the camp for seven days, and after that she may be brought in again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Miriam was shut out of the camp for seven days, and the people did not set out on the march until Miriam had been brought in again.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that the people set out from Hazeroth and camped in the wilderness of Paran.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Send men to spy out the land of Canaan, which I am giving to the Israelites; from each of their ancestral tribes you shall send a man, every one a leader among them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses sent them from the wilderness of Paran, according to the command of the Lord, all of them leading men among the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were their names: from the tribe of Reuben, Shammua son of Zaccur;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Simeon, Shaphat son of Hori;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Judah, Caleb son of Jephunneh;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Issachar, Igal son of Joseph;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Ephraim, Hoshea son of Nun;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Benjamin, Palti son of Raphu;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Zebulun, Gaddiel son of Sodi;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Joseph (that is, from the tribe of Manasseh), Gaddi son of Susi;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Dan, Ammiel son of Gemalli;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Asher, Sethur son of Michael;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Naphtali, Nahbi son of Vophsi;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the tribe of Gad, Geuel son of Machi.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the names of the men whom Moses sent to spy out the land. And Moses changed the name of Hoshea son of Nun to Joshua.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses sent them to spy out the land of Canaan and said to them, “Go up there into the Negeb, and go up into the hill country,
speaker: Narrator

text: and see what the land is like and whether the people who live in it are strong or weak, whether they are few or many,
speaker: Narrator

text: and whether the land they live in is good or bad, and whether the towns that they live in are unwalled or fortified,
speaker: Narrator

text: and whether the land is rich or poor, and whether there are trees in it or not. Be bold, and bring some of the fruit of the land.” Now it was the season of the first ripe grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went up and spied out the land from the wilderness of Zin to Rehob, near Lebo-hamath.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went up into the Negeb and came to Hebron, and Ahiman, Sheshai, and Talmai, the Anakites, were there. (Hebron was built seven years before Zoan in Egypt.)
speaker: Narrator

text: And they came to the Wadi Eshcol and cut down from there a branch with a single cluster of grapes, and they carried it on a pole between two of them. They also brought some pomegranates and figs.
speaker: Narrator

text: That place was called the Wadi Eshcol because of the cluster that the Israelites cut down from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of forty days they returned from spying out the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they came to Moses and Aaron and to all the congregation of the Israelites in the wilderness of Paran, at Kadesh; they brought back word to them and to all the congregation and showed them the fruit of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they reported to him and said, “We came to the land to which you sent us; it flows with milk and honey, and this is its fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the people who live in the land are strong, and the towns are fortified and very large, and besides, we saw the descendants of Anak there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Amalekites live in the land of the Negeb; the Hittites, the Jebusites, and the Amorites live in the hill country, and the Canaanites live by the sea and along the Jordan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Caleb quieted the people before Moses and said, “Let us go up at once and occupy it, for we are well able to overcome it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men who had gone up with him said, “We are not able to go up against this people, for they are stronger than we.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they brought to the Israelites an unfavorable report of the land that they had spied out, saying, “The land that we have gone through as spies is a land that devours its inhabitants, and all the people that we saw in it are of great size.
speaker: Narrator

text: There we saw the Nephilim (the Anakites come from the Nephilim), and to ourselves we seemed like grasshoppers, and so we seemed to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the congregation raised a loud cry, and the people wept that night.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the Israelites complained against Moses and Aaron; the whole congregation said to them, “Would that we had died in the land of Egypt! Or would that we had died in this wilderness!
speaker: Narrator

text: Why is the Lord bringing us into this land to fall by the sword? Our wives and our little ones will become plunder; would it not be better for us to go back to Egypt?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they said to one another, “Let us choose a captain and go back to Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron fell on their faces before all the assembly of the congregation of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Joshua son of Nun and Caleb son of Jephunneh, who were among those who had spied out the land, tore their clothes
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to all the congregation of the Israelites, “The land that we went through as spies is an exceedingly good land.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the Lord is pleased with us, he will bring us into this land and give it to us, a land that flows with milk and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only, do not rebel against the Lord, and do not fear the people of the land, for they are no more than bread for us; their protection is removed from them, and the Lord is with us; do not fear them.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the whole congregation threatened to stone them.
Then the glory of the Lord appeared at the tent of meeting to all the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to Moses, “How long will this people despise me? And how long will they refuse to believe in me, in spite of all the signs that I have done among them?
speaker: Narrator

text: I will strike them with pestilence and disinherit them, and I will make of you a nation greater and mightier than they.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said to the Lord, “Then the Egyptians will hear of it, for in your might you brought up this people from among them,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they will tell the inhabitants of this land. They have heard that you, O Lord, are in the midst of this people, for you, O Lord, are seen face to face, and your cloud stands over them and you go in front of them, in a pillar of cloud by day and in a pillar of fire by night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if you kill this people as one, then the nations who have heard about you will say,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘It is because the Lord was not able to bring this people into the land he swore to give them that he has slaughtered them in the wilderness.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, therefore, let the power of the Lord be great in the way that you promised when you spoke, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘The Lord is slow to anger
and abounding in steadfast love,
forgiving iniquity and transgression,
but by no means clearing the guilty,
visiting the iniquity of the parents
upon the children
to the third and the fourth generation.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Forgive the iniquity of this people according to the greatness of your steadfast love, just as you have pardoned this people, from Egypt even until now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “I do forgive, just as you have asked;
speaker: Narrator

text: nevertheless, as I live and as all the earth shall be filled with the glory of the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: none of the people who have seen my glory and the signs that I did in Egypt and in the wilderness and yet have tested me these ten times and have not obeyed my voice
speaker: Narrator

text: shall see the land that I swore to give to their ancestors; none of those who despised me shall see it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But my servant Caleb, because he has a different spirit and has followed me wholeheartedly, I will bring into the land into which he went, and his descendants shall possess it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, since the Amalekites and the Canaanites live in the valleys, turn tomorrow and set out for the wilderness by the way to the Red Sea.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord spoke to Moses and to Aaron, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “How long shall this wicked congregation complain against me? I have heard the complaints of the Israelites, which they complain against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to them, ‘As I live,’ says the Lord, ‘I will do to you the very things I heard you say:
speaker: Narrator

text: your dead bodies shall fall in this very wilderness, and of all your number included in the census from twenty years old and up who have complained against me,
speaker: Narrator

text: not one of you shall come into the land in which I swore to settle you, except Caleb son of Jephunneh and Joshua son of Nun.
speaker: Narrator

text: But your little ones, who you said would become plunder, I will bring in, and they shall know the land that you have despised.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for you, your dead bodies shall fall in this wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: And your children shall be shepherds in the wilderness for forty years and shall suffer for your faithlessness, until the last of your dead bodies lies in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: According to the number of the days in which you spied out the land, forty days, for every day a year, you shall bear your iniquity, forty years, and you shall know my displeasure.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I the Lord have spoken; surely I will do thus to all this wicked congregation gathered together against me: in this wilderness they shall come to a full end, and there they shall die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the men whom Moses sent to spy out the land who returned and made all the congregation complain against him by bringing a bad report about the land,
speaker: Narrator

text: the men who brought an unfavorable report about the land died by a plague before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joshua son of Nun and Caleb son of Jephunneh alone remained alive, of those men who went to spy out the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses told these words to all the Israelites, the people mourned greatly.
speaker: Narrator

text: They rose early in the morning and went up to the heights of the hill country, saying, “Here we are. We will go up to the place that the Lord has promised, for we have sinned.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “Why do you continue to transgress the command of the Lord? That will not succeed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not go up, for the Lord is not with you; do not let yourselves be struck down before your enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Amalekites and the Canaanites will confront you there, and you shall fall by the sword; because you have turned back from following the Lord, the Lord will not be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they presumed to go up to the heights of the hill country, even though the ark of the covenant of the Lord and Moses had not left the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Amalekites and the Canaanites who lived in that hill country came down and defeated them, pursuing them as far as Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and say to them: When you come into the land you are to inhabit, which I am giving you,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you make an offering by fire to the Lord from the herd or from the flock—whether a burnt offering or a sacrifice, to fulfill a vow or as a freewill offering or at your appointed festivals—to make a pleasing odor for the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: then whoever presents such an offering to the Lord shall present also a grain offering, one-tenth of an ephah of choice flour, mixed with one-fourth of a hin of oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, you shall offer one-fourth of a hin of wine as a drink offering with the burnt offering or the sacrifice, for each lamb.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a ram, you shall offer a grain offering, two-tenths of an ephah of choice flour mixed with one-third of a hin of oil,
speaker: Narrator

text: and as a drink offering you shall offer one-third of a hin of wine, a pleasing odor to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you offer a bull as a burnt offering or a sacrifice, to fulfill a vow or as an offering of well-being to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: then you shall present with the bull a grain offering, three-tenths of an ephah of choice flour, mixed with half a hin of oil,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you shall present as a drink offering half a hin of wine, as an offering by fire, a pleasing odor to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Thus it shall be done for each ox or ram or for each of the male lambs or the kids.
speaker: Narrator

text: According to the number that you offer, so you shall do with each and every one.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every native Israelite shall do these things in this way, in presenting an offering by fire, a pleasing odor to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: An alien who lives with you or who takes up permanent residence among you and wishes to offer an offering by fire, a pleasing odor to the Lord, shall do as you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the assembly, there shall be for both you and the resident alien a single statute, a perpetual statute throughout your generations; you and the alien shall be alike before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You and the alien who resides with you shall have the same law and the same ordinance.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and say to them: After you come into the land to which I am bringing you,
speaker: Narrator

text: whenever you eat of the bread of the land you shall present a donation to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: From your first batch of dough you shall present a loaf as a donation; you shall present it just as you present a donation from the threshing floor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Throughout your generations you shall give to the Lord a donation from the first of your batch of dough.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if you unintentionally fail to observe all these commandments that the Lord has spoken to Moses—
speaker: Narrator

text: everything that the Lord has commanded you by Moses, from the day the Lord gave commandment and thereafter, throughout your generations—
speaker: Narrator

text: then if it was done unintentionally without the knowledge of the congregation, the whole congregation shall offer one young bull for a burnt offering, a pleasing odor to the Lord, together with its grain offering and its drink offering, according to the ordinance, and one male goat for a purification offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest shall make atonement for all the congregation of the Israelites, and they shall be forgiven; it was unintentional, and they have brought their offering, an offering by fire to the Lord, and their purification offering before the Lord, for their error.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the congregation of the Israelites shall be forgiven, as well as the aliens residing among you, because the whole people was involved in the error.
speaker: Narrator

text: “An individual who sins unintentionally shall present a female goat a year old for a purification offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the priest shall make atonement before the Lord for the one who commits an error, when it is unintentional, to make atonement for the person, who then shall be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: For both the native among the Israelites and the alien residing among you, you shall have the same law for anyone who acts in error.
speaker: Narrator

text: But whoever acts high-handedly, whether native-born or an alien, affronts the Lord and shall be cut off from among the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of having despised the word of the Lord and broken his commandment, such a person shall be utterly cut off and bear the guilt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Israelites were in the wilderness, they found a man gathering sticks on the Sabbath day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who found him gathering sticks brought him to Moses, Aaron, and the whole congregation.
speaker: Narrator

text: They put him in custody because it was not clear what should be done to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “The man shall be put to death; all the congregation shall stone him outside the camp.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole congregation brought him outside the camp and stoned him to death, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites, and tell them to make fringes on the corners of their garments throughout their generations and to put a blue cord on the fringe at each corner.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have the fringe so that, when you see it, you will remember all the commandments of the Lord and do them and not follow the lust of your own heart and your own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you shall remember and do all my commandments, and you shall be holy to your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the Lord your God who brought you out of the land of Egypt to be your God: I am the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Korah son of Izhar son of Kohath son of Levi, along with Dathan and Abiram sons of Eliab, and On son of Peleth son of Reuben, took
speaker: Narrator

text: two hundred fifty Israelite men, leaders of the congregation, chosen from the assembly, well-known men, and they confronted Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: They assembled against Moses and against Aaron and said to them, “You have gone too far! All the congregation are holy, every one of them, and the Lord is among them. So why then do you exalt yourselves above the assembly of the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses heard it, he fell on his face.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he spoke to Korah and all his congregation, saying, “In the morning the Lord will make known who is his and who is holy and who will be allowed to approach him; the one whom he will choose he will allow to approach him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this: take censers, Korah and all your congregation,
speaker: Narrator

text: and tomorrow put fire in them, and lay incense on them before the Lord, and the man whom the Lord chooses shall be the holy one. You Levites have gone too far!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to Korah, “Hear now, you Levites!
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it too little for you that the God of Israel has separated you from the congregation of Israel to allow you to approach him in order to perform the duties of the Lord’s tabernacle and to stand before the congregation and serve them?
speaker: Narrator

text: He has allowed you to approach him, and all your brother Levites with you, yet you seek the priesthood as well!
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore you and all your congregation have gathered together against the Lord. What is Aaron that you rail against him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses sent for Dathan and Abiram sons of Eliab, but they said, “We will not come!
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it too little that you have brought us up out of a land flowing with milk and honey to kill us in the wilderness, that you must also lord it over us?
speaker: Narrator

text: It is clear you have not brought us into a land flowing with milk and honey or given us an inheritance of fields and vineyards. Would you put out the eyes of these men? We will not come!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was very angry and said to the Lord, “Pay no attention to their offering. I have not taken one donkey from them, and I have not harmed any one of them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses said to Korah, “As for you and all your congregation, be present tomorrow before the Lord, you and they and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: and let each one of you take his censer and put incense on it and each one of you present his censer before the Lord, two hundred fifty censers, you also, and Aaron, each his censer.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So each man took his censer, and they put fire in the censers and laid incense on them, and they stood at the entrance of the tent of meeting with Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Korah assembled the whole congregation against them at the entrance of the tent of meeting. And the glory of the Lord appeared to the whole congregation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses and to Aaron, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Separate yourselves from this congregation, so that I may consume them in a moment.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They fell on their faces and said, “O God, the God of the spirits of all flesh, shall one person sin and you become angry with the whole congregation?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the congregation, saying: Get away from the dwellings of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses got up and went to Dathan and Abiram; the elders of Israel followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He spoke to the congregation, saying, “Turn away from the tents of these wicked men and touch nothing of theirs, or you will be swept away for all their sins.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they got away from the dwellings of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram, and Dathan and Abiram came out and stood at the entrances of their tents, together with their wives, their children, and their little ones.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses said, “This is how you shall know that the Lord has sent me to do all these works; it has not been of my own accord:
speaker: Narrator

text: If these people die a natural death or if a natural fate comes on them, then the Lord has not sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the Lord creates something new and the ground opens its mouth and swallows them up, with all that belongs to them, and they go down alive into Sheol, then you shall know that these men have despised the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he finished speaking all these words, the ground under them was split apart.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth opened its mouth and swallowed them up, along with their households—everyone who belonged to Korah and all their goods.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they with all that belonged to them went down alive into Sheol; the earth closed over them, and they perished from the midst of the assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel around them fled at their outcry, for they said, “The earth will swallow us, too!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And fire came out from the Lord and consumed the two hundred fifty men offering the incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Eleazar son of Aaron the priest to take the censers out of the blaze, then scatter the fire far and wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the censers of these sinners have become holy at the cost of their lives. Make them into hammered plates as a covering for the altar, for they presented them before the Lord and they became holy. Thus they shall be a sign to the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Eleazar the priest took the bronze censers that had been presented by those who were burned, and they were hammered out as a covering for the altar—
speaker: Narrator

text: a reminder to the Israelites that no outsider, who is not of the descendants of Aaron, shall approach to offer incense before the Lord, so as not to become like Korah and his congregation, just as the Lord had said to him through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day, however, the whole congregation of the Israelites rebelled against Moses and against Aaron, saying, “You have killed the people of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the congregation had assembled against them, Moses and Aaron turned toward the tent of meeting; the cloud had covered it, and the glory of the Lord appeared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron came to the front of the tent of meeting,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Get away from this congregation, so that I may consume them in a moment.” And they fell on their faces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Aaron, “Take your censer, put fire on it from the altar and lay incense on it and carry it quickly to the congregation and make atonement for them. For wrath has gone out from the Lord; the plague has begun.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Aaron took it as Moses had ordered and ran into the middle of the assembly, where the plague had already begun among the people. He put on the incense and made atonement for the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stood between the dead and the living, and the plague was stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who died by the plague were fourteen thousand seven hundred, besides those who died in the affair of Korah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the plague was stopped, Aaron returned to Moses at the entrance of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites, and get twelve staffs from them, one for each ancestral house, from all the leaders of their ancestral houses. Write each man’s name on his staff,
speaker: Narrator

text: and write Aaron’s name on the staff of Levi. For there shall be one staff for the head of each ancestral house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Place them in the tent of meeting before the covenant, where I meet with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the staff of the man whom I choose shall sprout; thus I will put a stop to the complaints of the Israelites that they continually make against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses spoke to the Israelites, and all their leaders gave him staffs, one for each leader, according to their ancestral houses, twelve staffs; and the staff of Aaron was among theirs.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses placed the staffs before the Lord in the tent of the covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses went into the tent of the covenant on the next day, the staff of Aaron for the house of Levi had sprouted. It put forth buds, produced blossoms, and bore ripe almonds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses brought out all the staffs from before the Lord to all the Israelites, and they looked, and each man took his staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to Moses, “Put back the staff of Aaron before the covenant, to be kept as a warning to rebels, so that you may make an end of their complaints against me, or else they will die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses did so; just as the Lord commanded him, so he did.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites said to Moses, “We are perishing; we are lost; all of us are lost!
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who approaches the tabernacle of the Lord will die. Are we all to perish?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Aaron, “You and your sons and your ancestral house with you shall bear responsibility for offenses connected with the sanctuary, while you and your sons alone shall bear responsibility for offenses connected with the priesthood.
speaker: Narrator

text: So bring with you also your brothers of the tribe of Levi, your ancestral tribe, in order that they may be joined to you and serve you while you and your sons with you are in front of the tent of the covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall perform duties for you and for the whole tent. But they must not approach either the utensils of the sanctuary or the altar, or else both they and you will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are attached to you in order to perform the duties of the tent of meeting, for all the service of the tent; no outsider shall approach you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You yourselves shall perform the duties of the sanctuary and the duties of the altar, so that wrath may never again come upon the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is I who now take your brother Levites from among the Israelites; they are now yours as a gift, dedicated to the Lord, to perform the service of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you and your sons with you shall diligently perform your priestly duties in all that concerns the altar and the area behind the curtain. I give your priesthood as a gift; any outsider who approaches shall be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Aaron, “I have given you charge of the offerings made to me, all the holy gifts of the Israelites; I have given them to you and your sons as a priestly portion due you in perpetuity.
speaker: Narrator

text: This shall be yours from the most holy things, reserved from the fire: every offering of theirs that they render to me as a most holy thing, whether grain offering, purification offering, or guilt offering, shall belong to you and your sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a most holy thing you shall eat it; every male may eat it; it shall be holy to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: This also is yours: I have given to you, together with your sons and daughters, as a perpetual due, whatever is set aside from the gifts of all the elevation offerings of the Israelites; everyone who is clean in your house may eat them.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the best of the oil and all the best of the wine and of the grain, the choice produce that they give to the Lord, I have given to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first fruits of all that is in their land that they bring to the Lord shall be yours; everyone who is clean in your house may eat of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every devoted thing in Israel shall be yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first issue of the womb of all creatures, human and animal, that is offered to the Lord shall be yours, but the firstborn of human beings you shall redeem, and the firstborn of unclean animals you shall redeem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their redemption price, reckoned from one month of age, you shall fix at five shekels of silver, according to the shekel of the sanctuary (that is, twenty gerahs).
speaker: Narrator

text: But the firstborn of a cow or the firstborn of a sheep or the firstborn of a goat you shall not redeem; they are holy. You shall dash their blood on the altar and turn their fat into smoke as an offering by fire for a pleasing odor to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: but their flesh shall be yours, just as the breast that is elevated and as the right thigh are yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the holy offerings that the Israelites present to the Lord I have given to you, together with your sons and daughters, as a perpetual due; it is a covenant of salt forever before the Lord for you and your descendants as well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Aaron, “You shall have no allotment in their land, nor shall you have any share among them; I am your share and your possession among the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: “To the Levites I have given every tithe in Israel for a possession in return for the service that they perform, the service in the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: From now on the Israelites shall no longer approach the tent of meeting, or else they will incur guilt and die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Levites shall perform the service of the tent of meeting, and they shall bear responsibility for their own offenses; it shall be a perpetual statute throughout your generations. But among the Israelites they shall have no allotment,
speaker: Narrator

text: because I have given to the Levites as their portion the tithe of the Israelites, which they set apart as an offering to the Lord. Therefore I have said of them that they shall have no allotment among the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall say to the Levites: When you receive from the Israelites the tithe that I have given you from them for your portion, you shall set apart an offering from it to the Lord, a tithe of the tithe.
speaker: Narrator

text: It shall be reckoned to you as your gift, the same as the grain of the threshing floor and the fullness of the winepress.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus you also shall set apart an offering to the Lord from all the tithes that you receive from the Israelites, and from them you shall give the Lord’s offering to the priest Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of all the gifts to you, you shall set apart every offering due to the Lord; the best of all of them is the part to be consecrated.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say also to them: When you have set apart the best of it, then the rest shall be reckoned to the Levites as produce of the threshing floor and as produce of the winepress.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may eat it in any place, you and your households, for it is your payment for your service in the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall incur no guilt by reason of it, when you have offered the best of it. But you shall not profane the holy gifts of the Israelites, on pain of death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is a statute of the law that the Lord has commanded: Tell the Israelites to bring you a red heifer without defect, in which there is no blemish and on which no yoke has been laid.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall give it to the priest Eleazar, and it shall be taken outside the camp and slaughtered in his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest Eleazar shall take some of its blood with his finger and sprinkle it seven times toward the front of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the heifer shall be burned in his sight; its skin, its flesh, and its blood, with its entrails, shall be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest shall take cedarwood, hyssop, and crimson material and throw them into the fire in which the heifer is burning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest shall wash his clothes and bathe his body in water, and afterward he may come into the camp, but the priest shall remain unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who burns the heifer shall wash his clothes in water and bathe his body in water; he shall remain unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then someone who is clean shall gather up the ashes of the heifer and deposit them outside the camp in a clean place, and they shall be kept for the congregation of the Israelites for the water for cleansing. It is a purification offering.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The one who gathers the ashes of the heifer shall wash his clothes and be unclean until evening.
“This shall be a perpetual statute for the Israelites and for the alien residing among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who touch the dead body of any human being shall be unclean seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall purify themselves with the water on the third day and on the seventh day and so be clean, but if they do not purify themselves on the third day and on the seventh day, they will not become clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: All who touch a corpse, the body of a human being who has died, and do not purify themselves defile the tabernacle of the Lord; such persons shall be cut off from Israel. Since water for cleansing was not dashed on them, they remain unclean; their uncleanness is still on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the law when someone dies in a tent: everyone who comes into the tent and everyone who is in the tent shall be unclean seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: And every open vessel with no cover fastened on it is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever in the open field touches one who has been killed by a sword or who has died naturally, or a human bone, or a grave shall be unclean seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the unclean they shall take some ashes of the burnt purification offering, and running water shall be added in a vessel;
speaker: Narrator

text: then a clean person shall take hyssop, dip it in the water, and sprinkle it on the tent, on all the furnishings, on the persons who were there, and on whoever touched the bone, the slain, the corpse, or the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text: The clean person shall sprinkle the unclean ones on the third day and on the seventh day, thus purifying them on the seventh day. Then they shall wash their clothes and bathe themselves in water, and at evening they shall be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any who are unclean but do not purify themselves, those persons shall be cut off from the assembly, for they have defiled the sanctuary of the Lord. Since the water for cleansing has not been dashed on them, they are unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “It shall be a perpetual statute for them. The one who sprinkles the water for cleansing shall wash his clothes, and whoever touches the water for cleansing shall be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever the unclean person touches shall be unclean, and anyone who touches it shall be unclean until evening.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites, the whole congregation, came into the wilderness of Zin in the first month, and the people stayed in Kadesh. Miriam died there and was buried there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was no water for the congregation, so they gathered together against Moses and against Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people quarreled with Moses and said, “Would that we had died when our kindred died before the Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text: Why have you brought the assembly of the Lord into this wilderness for us and our livestock to die here?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why have you brought us up out of Egypt to bring us to this wretched place? It is no place for grain or figs or vines or pomegranates, and there is no water to drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron went away from the assembly to the entrance of the tent of meeting; they fell on their faces, and the glory of the Lord appeared to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the staff, and assemble the congregation, you and your brother Aaron, and command the rock before their eyes to yield its water. Thus you shall bring water out of the rock for them; thus you shall provide drink for the congregation and their livestock.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses took the staff from before the Lord, as he had commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron gathered the assembly together before the rock, and he said to them, “Listen, you rebels; shall we bring water for you out of this rock?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses lifted up his hand and struck the rock twice with his staff; water came out abundantly, and the congregation and their livestock drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Because you did not trust in me, to show my holiness before the eyes of the Israelites, therefore you shall not bring this assembly into the land that I have given them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the waters of Meribah, where the Israelites quarreled with the Lord and through which he showed himself to be holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses sent messengers from Kadesh to the king of Edom, “Thus says your brother Israel: You know all the adversity that has befallen us,
speaker: Narrator

text: how our ancestors went down to Egypt, and we lived in Egypt a long time, and the Egyptians oppressed us and our ancestors,
speaker: Narrator

text: and when we cried to the Lord, he heard our voice and sent an angel and brought us out of Egypt, and here we are in Kadesh, a town on the edge of your territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now let us pass through your land. We will not pass through field or vineyard or drink water from any well; we will go along the King’s Highway, not turning aside to the right hand or to the left until we have passed through your territory.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Edom said to him, “You shall not pass through, or we will come out with the sword against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites said to him, “We will stay on the highway, and if we drink of your water, we and our livestock, then we will pay for it. It is only a small matter; just let us pass through on foot.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “You shall not pass through.” And Edom came out against them with a large force, heavily armed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus Edom refused to give Israel passage through their territory, so Israel turned away from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set out from Kadesh, and the Israelites, the whole congregation, came to Mount Hor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron at Mount Hor, on the border of the land of Edom,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let Aaron be gathered to his people. For he shall not enter the land that I have given to the Israelites, because you rebelled against my command at the waters of Meribah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take Aaron and his son Eleazar, and bring them up Mount Hor;
speaker: Narrator

text: strip Aaron of his vestments, and put them on his son Eleazar. But Aaron shall be gathered to his people and shall die there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses did as the Lord had commanded; they went up Mount Hor in the sight of the whole congregation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses stripped Aaron of his vestments and put them on his son Eleazar, and Aaron died there on the top of the mountain. Moses and Eleazar came down from the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the congregation saw that Aaron had died, all the house of Israel mourned for Aaron thirty days.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Canaanite, the king of Arad, who lived in the Negeb, heard that Israel was coming by the way of Atharim, he fought against Israel and took some of them captive.
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord listened to the voice of Israel and handed over the Canaanites, and they utterly destroyed them and their towns; so the place was called Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Mount Hor they set out by the way to the Red Sea, to go around the land of Edom, but the people became discouraged on the way.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people spoke against God and against Moses, “Why have you brought us up out of Egypt to die in the wilderness? For there is no food and no water, and we detest this miserable food.”
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses made a serpent of bronze and put it upon a pole, and whenever a serpent bit someone, that person would look at the serpent of bronze and live.

text: The Israelites set out and camped in Oboth.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set out from Oboth and camped at Iye-abarim, in the wilderness bordering Moab toward the sunrise.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they set out and camped in the Wadi Zered.
speaker: Narrator

the well that the leaders sank,

From the wilderness to Mattanah,

text: Thus Israel settled in the land of the Amorites.
